Parent 1 has a dominant allele (B) that determines its blue phenotype, so its genotype can be written as BB or B_ (where the underscore indicates that the B allele is masked by dominance).
Parent 2 also has a dominant allele (B) that determines its blue phenotype, so its genotype can be written as BB or B_ (where the underscore indicates that the B allele is masked by dominance).

According to the Punnett square for this cross, the possible genotypes for the offspring are:
BB (which will result in a blue phenotype),
B_ (which will result in a blue phenotype), and
G_ (which will result in a green phenotype).

BB: 1/4 (requires both parents to have the BB genotype).
B_: 1/2 (requires one parent to have the BB genotype and one parent to have the B_ genotype).
G_: 1/4 (requires both parents to have the B_ genotype).

Parent 1: BB or B_ (both are possible).
Parent 2: BB or B_ (both are possible).
Offspring: BB, B_, or G_ (with probabilities 1/4, 1/2, and 1/4, respectively).

data.sampled:
I'm not sure if I understand your question fully. How does Turquoise fit into this? From your description and the example case you provided I understand the following: A beetle can have the wing color blue, green or turquoise. Blue is dominant to both green and turquoise, while green is dominant to turquoise.

When two blue beetles are crossed the offspring will inherent a blue and a non blue allele. They will appear blue as blue is dominant. You wrote this as "BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_". However, I think it's better to write BB x BB -> BB_/BB_. The first BB indicates the genes inherent by the first beetle, and the second BB indicates the genes inherent by the second beetle. The B_ indicates the dominant allele, in this case  blue. The / indicates that the other allele is not blue, and because green is dominant over turquoise the offspring are BB_.

I think you want me to calculate the possible distributions when you cross a blue beetle with a heterozygous blue beetle. Because the parent beetle always inherents a blue allele its genotype will be BB. Because the other parent beetle inherits one blue allele, and one non blue allele its genotype will be B__.

The child will inherit one of its parent's genes. So the child's genotype will be BB or B_. Because blue is dominant to both green and turquoise, the only possible offspring will be blue. The ratio will be 1/2 x BB: 1/2 x B_. However, as the child's phenotype will be blue for all cases this should be written as BB/B_.
